text: heavy security remains in place and
indian-administered Kashmir as people
prepare to celebrate the Muslim festival
of Eid some large mosques are expected
to remain closed in the Muslim majority
territory small and lots though are open
to worshipers the region has largely
been in lockdown since India announced a
week ago that it was revoking Kashmir
special semi-autonomous status the
Indian government has said that law and
order has been maintained across
indian-administered Kashmir during Eid
but with internet and phone services
still cut off reporting from Kashmir is
extremely difficult
our correspondent and the main city
stronger egaita lamb I recorded this
report for us late on Sunday but was
only able to get it through to us in the
last few hours the curfew restrictions
which had been eased somewhat over the
past two days are being strictly
enforced again now there are fewer
people and vehicles out on the streets
than we've seen in the two days before
this it's unclear why this action was
taken we were actually able to ask a
government spokesman about it according
to him there is no curfew in place just
rules that don't allow more than four
people to gather in any place at a time
however police vans have been doing the
rounds in the city saying that there's a
curfew in place and that people should
stay indoors so quite a mixed message
that's being sent across phone and
internet lines remain cut off for nearly
a week now people aren't able to
communicate with each other
indian-administered Kashmir remains
volatile and tense since Monday when the
national government revoked this
region's special status on Friday mass
protests took place in a part of Sri
Nagar in which thousands of people
participated it was filmed by a BBC team
[Applause]
in it you can see people running to
safety you can hear gunshots be fired
there are reports that people have been
injured in that process but we aren't
able to go to the hospital being stopped
either by angry locals or by security
forces
we were however able to put a question
about it to a government spokesperson
are there any casualties in hospital so
you see the police has already made a
detailed statement yesterday about that
that there was absolutely no firing not
a single gunshot was fired and that is
it not much clarity in his answer there
and the Ministry of Home Affairs of the
national government has denied claims
that any protest larger than 20 people
took place in Srinagar
well as tensions increased people living
near the line of control fear a
potential cross-border fire between
India and Pakistan some of them have
already left many others cannot leave
BBC adores fat Javed has visited a
village close to the line of control and
pakistan-administered Kashmir
Najma bibi was living a peaceful life
until recently in a remote village at
the linus control now she is one of many
who have left their homes fearing a
military escalation between India and
Pakistan her family will stay in
Muzaffarabad for at least a month a
varsity bomb necklace when we left home
we couldn't collect all of the luggage I
packed some of my kids items and left
others look some of the doors and left
for the city people in the village keep
sitting in bunkers all night long
they just stay up all night they were at
the puddi puddi rod this is a common
sight in many villages near the line of
control there divides the disputed
region of Kashmir between India and
Pakistan both the countries blame each
other for ceasefire violations and
targeting civilians every now and then
when shelling continues for days
villagers move to the safer cities life
looks normal in the cities of Pakistan
administered Kashmir but there is a
sense of uncertainty among people we
don't know what will happen in the next
24 hours we are worried because we don't
know about the well-being of our
relatives who live on the other side of
line of control when the situation
worsens our business is also affected
then we keep sitting idle I don't see
buyers for months afterwards people in
Pakistan administered Kashmir have been
holding anti-india rallies for a v-plow
among them are few groups who are
against both India and Pakistan they
want a sovereign Kashmir predominate
majority Pakistan former Chief Justice
Manuel husband says there is no chance
of war between the two nuclear neighbors
but situation Indian side of Kashmir may
remain violent schottky you make a law
according to the will and benefited the
people what the government has done it
was not demanded by the people it's made
against the wishes of the people so how
can it work
what cantilever fuel kilometers from the
line of control and lying in the heart
of pakistan-administered Kashmir this
city has been one of the safest
destinations for those affected by
ceasefire violations but this time it is
feared that if secure wishes intensify
